Mixing household bleach (sodium hypochlorite) and ammonia produces toxic chloramine gases (and in some conditions other related compounds). These gases can seriously irritate or damage the eyes, nose, throat and lungs and at higher concentrations can cause chemical pneumonitis, pulmonary edema, or even be life‑threatening.

What happens and why it’s dangerous (brief)
- Bleach + ammonia → chloramines (monochloramine, dichloramine, nitrogen trichloride).  
- These vapors irritate the respiratory tract; heavy exposure can cause coughing, shortness of breath, chest pain, vomiting, and fluid in the lungs.  
- Symptoms can appear quickly but in some cases may be delayed.  
- (Different but related hazard: bleach + acids produce chlorine gas, also very dangerous.)

2. Ventilate the space (open windows/doors) but only if it’s safe to do so.  
3. Move anyone who feels unwell to fresh air. If anyone has trouble breathing, chest pain, severe coughing, fainting, or severe eye irritation, call emergency services right away.  
4. If there’s eye or skin exposure, flush with water for 15–20 minutes and seek medical attention.  
5. Call your local poison control center for guidance (in the U.S. 1-800-222-1222). If outside the U.S., call local emergency services or your country’s poison control number.

- Never mix cleaning products. Read labels — most will warn against mixing.  
- Use one product at a time and rinse the surface before using another.  
- For disinfecting: diluted household bleach (follow label instructions) or 70% isopropyl alcohol for small surfaces.  
- For windows/glass: ammonia-based glass cleaners are fine alone — just don’t combine with bleach.  
- For general cleaning: soap/detergent and water are safe and effective for most jobs.

- “I know that’s an old trick, but mixing bleach and ammonia creates toxic gases that can seriously harm our lungs. Let’s stop doing that — we can use one cleaner at a time or a safer alternative.”
